Effect of physicochemical properties of carbons on the performance of bead-type Pd/C catalysts for furfural hydrogenation Gangmin Kim Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation a b Ye Eun Kim Writing – review & editing Conceptualization a c Jungho Jae Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Man Sig Lee Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization a ⁎ a Ulsan Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology (KITECH), Ulsan 44413, South Korea Ulsan Division Korea Institute of Industrial Technology (KITECH) Ulsan 44413 South Korea aUlsan Division, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology (KITECH), Ulsan 44413, South Korea b School of Chemical Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan 46241, South Korea School of Chemical Engineering Pusan National University Busan 46241 South Korea bSchool of Chemical Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan 46241, South Korea c Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul 02841, South Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University Seoul 02841 South Korea cDepartment of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul 02841, South Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. In green heterogeneous catalytic systems, alginate has emerged as a promising material for transforming powder catalysts into solid forms because of its sustainability and non-toxicity. Herein, the effect of carbon supports, including activated carbon (AC), carbon black (CB), carbon nanotubes (CNT), and carbon nanofibers (CNF), on a bead-type Pd/alginate-carbon catalyst was studied. Bead-type supports were synthesized by alginate gelation, and Pd-supported bead-type catalysts were prepared by a chemical reduction method. The catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of furfural was evaluated. Physical properties such as the specific surface area and pore volume of the carbon support greatly influenced the properties of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst. Pd/CB-alginate bead (AB), which had the highest specific surface area and pore volume, exhibited the smallest Pd particle size and dispersion, resulting in the highest catalytic performance. Additionally, the catalyst exhibited the highest FF conversion of 99 % and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol selectivity of 92 % under 20 bar of H2 at 35 ℃ for 4 h. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alginate Bead-type Pd/C catalyst Carbon support Furfural Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal-nanoparticle catalysts are widely used in hydrogenation reactions [1]. Among these, palladium has received considerable attention in the field of catalysis because of its high performance in catalytic reactions and its ability to dissociate hydrogen under mild conditions [2–4]. Owing to the high cost and aggregation of palladium in reaction mixtures, palladium must be dispersed on supports such as carbon and metal oxides. To use Pd in industrial catalysis applications, shaping of the catalyst is essential for facilitating its recovery, reusability, handling, and separation. Catalyst shaping has been utilized to improve the scale-up of processes and reduce the ratio of the catalyst mass to reactor volume [5]. Bead catalysts have a unique spherical morphology, unlike granules or pellets, that is exposed to less mechanical damage and has a higher packing density [6,7]. Conventional methods of fabricating bead-type catalysts, such as spray drying and dropping particles into an oil-bath, require high temperatures for drying, and the manufacturing facility is expensive and complicated. Developing green heterogeneous catalysts has been the focus of many studies owing to the sustainability, recyclability, and minimal waste associated with such catalysts [8,9]. Biopolymers such as alginate, chitosan, and pectin have received considerable attention in the field of green catalyst supports owing to their low cost, biodegradability, and non-toxicity [10–12]. Alginate is a prominent biopolymer that can form spherical hydrogel beads via ionotropic gelation when dropped into a solution containing bivalent cations. Alginate is a natural polysaccharide extracted from the cell walls of brown algae. Alginate contains abundant carboxylate (-COO-) and hydroxyl functional groups (-OH) that stabilize metal particles. The chemical stability and porous structure of alginate hydrogels render them potential materials for use as catalyst supports [12–14]. However, alginate as a catalyst support still has some drawbacks, such as low mechanical strength and a low saturated metal loading content [13,15]. One technique for improving the stability of alginate catalysts is the incorporation of polymers or carbon into the alginate[16–18]. Most studies have focused on incorporating alginate into carbon, which is used as an adsorbent [19–21] or catalyst support [22,23], whereas no studies have reported the effect of the properties of carbon on carbon-alginate beads. With the increasing demand for eco-friendly products and efforts to replace petroleum-based materials, upgrading biomass is a promising way to produce renewable fuels and chemicals [24–26]. Furfural (FF) is an important platform material derived from lignocellulose biomass feedstock. FF can be transformed into valuable chemicals such as furan, furfuryl alcohol (FAL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFAL), 2-methylfuran, tetrahydrofurfural (THFF), and cyclopentanone through hydrogenation reactions. THFAL is a degradable, less-toxic, and stable saturated furan compound commonly used in green solvents. It can also be used as a chemical intermediate between 1,5-petanediol and 1,2-petanediol, which are key chemicals in the plastic industry [27–30]. In this study, we investigate the effects of the carbon structure on the properties of bead-type Pd/C catalysts. Carbon beads are prepared by ionotropic gelation, and various carbons with different structures, including carbon black (CB), activated carbon (AC), carbon nanotubes (CNT), and carbon nanofibers (CNF), are used as supports. For preparing the bead-type Pd/C catalysts, sodium alginate is dropped into a CaCl2 solution to form a spherical bead support, which acts as a biopolymer template. The bead-type Pd/C catalysts are prepared using a chemical reduction method. The prepared bead-type Pd/C catalysts are investigated using N2 adsorption and desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO chemisorption, and field-emission scanning (and transmission) electron microscopy (FE-SEM and FE-TEM). The catalytic performance is evaluated in FF hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pristine carbon black (CB) (Black Pearl 2000) was purchased from Cabot Co., Ltd Carbon nanotubes (CNT) was purchased from Applied Carbon Nanotechnology and carbon nanofibers (CNF) was purchased from Carbon Nanomaterial Technology. The carbons were pretreated with 4 M sulfuric acid and nitric acid (1:1 v/v) by sonication at room temperature for 2 h for surface functionalization. Activated carbon (AC), calcium chloride, sodium alginate, trisodium alginate, and sodium borohydride were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of carbon-alginate bead support An alginate solution (2 %, w/v) was prepared by pouring sodium alginate (3.0 g) into 150 mL of deionized water and stirring for 2 h to obtain a homogeneous solution. Thereafter, 4 g of carbon was added to the mixture and mixed using a homogenizer at 4000 rpm for 2 h [19]. To form the carbon-alginate hydrogel beads, a homogeneous alginate-carbon solution was added dropwise to a solution of 4% (w/v) calcium chloride with slow stirring for 2 h. The beads were then washed thrice with deionized water to remove excess sodium and calcium ions. The washed beads were stored in water until further use. 2.3 Preparation of Pd/carbon-alginate bead catalysts Spherical Pd/C-AB catalysts were synthesized using a chemical reduction method and reduced with sodium borohydride. H2PdCl4 (0.1 M) was dissolved in 100 ml of a 0.526 mM trisodium tartrate solution under stirring at 200 rpm at 5 ℃. Thereafter, 19 g of the wet C-AB support was added to the Pd precursor solution and stirred continuously for 24 h. After continuous stirring, 100 ml of 0.3 M sodium borohydride solution was added dropwise to the solution and stirred for 2 h to reduce the Pd2+ ions. Finally, the resulting black spherical beads were washed, filtered, and then dried using a freeze dryer. Through this process, Pd-supported bead-type catalysts, Pd/AC-AB (alginate beads), Pd/CB-AB, Pd/CNT-AB, and Pd/CNF-AB, were prepared. 2.4 Characterization Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were obtained using a low-vacuum scanning electron microscope (JEOL, JSM-6490LV). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas and pore volumes were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired using a Rigaku D/MAX 2500-V/PC instrument at 50 kV/50 mA, with a Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å). The Raman spectra were obtained using a Thermo Scientific DXR Raman microscope equipped with a 532 nm excitation laser. Field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM) images were obtained using a JEM-2100 F (JEOL) instrument, at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The average Pd particle size distributions were obtained using ImageJ software by counting 100 spherical Pd particles. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TGA-DSC2 instrument (Mettler Toledo), under nitrogen atmosphere, at a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1. To determine the dispersion and metallic surface area of Pd, CO chemisorption analysis was performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. 2.5 Catalytic hydrogenation over bead-type Pd/C catalysts The liquid-phase hydrogenation of FF was performed in a 100 ml stainless autoclave reactor using 1.56 mmol of FF and 20 mL of 2-propanol as the solvent. First, 0.05 g of catalyst was added to the reactor. The autoclave reactor was purged twice with nitrogen and hydrogen gas twice, respectively, to eliminate air inside the autoclave. The reactor was then heated to 35 ℃ with magnetic stirring at rate of 700 rpm to conduct the hydrogenation reaction. After the reaction, the mixtures were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7820 A, FID) equipped with an Agilent DB-WAX column. The conversion and selectivity were calculated using the following equations: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e FF , initial − m o l e FF , final m o l e FF , initial × 100 % S e l e c i t v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s p e c i f i c p r o d u c t m o l e t o t a l p r o d u c t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Bead-type carbon-alginate supports were synthesized by the ionic crosslinking method, and bead-type Pd/C catalysts were prepared by a chemical reduction method using NaBH4 as the reducing agent. As shown in Fig. 1 , the acid treatment of carbon introduced carboxyl (-COOH) and hydroxyl (-OH) groups onto the carbon surface and functionalized the oxygen-containing functional groups of carbon bonded to the alginate chain by covalent bonding [31,32]. The Pd nanoparticles were stabilized by the abundant oxygen functional groups of the alginate and the carbon surface [33]. Freeze drying maintained the porosity of the carbon-alginate hydrogel during the drying process. SEM images of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst showed black, macroscopic beads with diameters of 4–7 mm, and it was confirmed that the surface morphology and size of the catalysts depended on the carbon structure (Fig. 2 ). The average diameter of the Pd/AC-AB, Pd/CB-AB, Pd/CNT-AB, and Pd/CNF-AB catalysts was 4.93, 5.84, 6.70, and 6.21 mm, respectively. The SEM images showed different structures of various carbons in the form of AC, CB, CNT, and CNF encapsulated in alginate (Fig. S1). The Pd/AC-AB and Pd/CNF-AB catalysts had a relatively smooth surface surrounded by alginate because of the large particle size of carbon, whereas the Pd/CB-AB and Pd/CNT-AB catalysts had rough alginate surfaces. These results demonstrate that macroscale beads with carbon on alginate can be obtained using a simple preparation method. Fig.3 shows the N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the carbon supports and the Table 1 summarizes the physical properties of the carbon supports. CB, CNT, and CNF showed type-IV isotherms with an H2(b) hysteresis loop (Fig. 3a) representing mesoporous structure with large neck-widths pores. On the contrary, AC exhibited type-IV isotherms with an H4 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of micropores and the formation of slit-shaped pores [34]. Furthermore, the pore size distributions of the carbon supports exhibited in Fig. 3(a). According to the IUPAC classification, pores were divided in to their size with micropores (<2 nm), mesopores (2–50 nm), and macropores (>50 nm). CNT and CNF showed mesoporous structure, while CB showed the combination with the mesopores and micropores. On the other hand, AC showed microporous structure with the lowest pore volume. The specific surface areas of the carbon supports decreased in the following order: CB > AC > CNT > CNF. Compared to the other pristine carbons, CB had the excellent physical properties of specific surface area (1342.3 m2/g) and pore volume (1.5 cm3/g) than other carbon supports. As depicted in the Fig. 3(b), the N2 isotherms of all bead-type Pd/C catalysts were similar to the isotherms of the carbon support, indicating that the incorporation of alginate and the deposition of Pd did not induce significant change in the pore structure of the pristine carbons. Table 2 listed the textural properties of the bead-type Pd/C catalysts. The physical properties of bead-type catalysts are highly influenced by the nature of the carbon. The specific surface area and pore volume of all the bead-type Pd/C catalysts significantly decreased compared to those of the carbon supports owing to pore blocking by alginate, which is in accordance with the literature [35]. As can be seen in the decreasing total pore volume ratio between the carbon support and the bead-type Pd/C catalyst, AC (67 %), CB (41 %), CNT (45 %), and CNF (61 %) were shown. In the case of AC and CB, micropore volume showed a significant decrease (70 %) than mesopores (35–40 %), indicating alginate blocks more micropores than mesopores. To evaluate the thermal stability of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst, TGA curves of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst and Pd/alginate beads (AB) were acquired under a flow of nitrogen gas (Fig. 4 ). The TGA curves of the bead-type Pd/C catalysts were above those of Pd/AB, indicating that the former exhibited less thermal degradation, demonstrating better thermal stability than alginate alone. All the catalysts exhibited three steps of weight loss in the range of 25‒800 ℃. In the first stage at temperatures below 200 ℃, the Pd/C-AB catalysts underwent approximately 10 % weight loss, compared with 18 % in the Pd/AB catalyst, due to the evaporation of residual water from the catalysts. Thus, it can be inferred that Pd/C-AB absorbed less water than Pd/AB, indicating that the incorporated carbon reduced the hygroscopicity of the catalyst. In the range of 200‒350 ℃, the saccharide rings and oxygen functional groups degraded more rapidly [36]. Above 350 ℃, the carbonaceous materials decomposed, as the final steps [37]. Pd/AB exhibited an approximately 70 % weight loss, whereas the weight loss of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst was 40 %. The catalysts that incorporated carbon exhibited enhanced thermal stability compared with alginate alone. The crystal structures and phase compositions of the bead-type Pd/C catalysts were confirmed by XRD analysis (Fig. 5 ). The XRD pattern of alginate consisted of two diffraction peaks at 2θ = 13.4° and 22.7°[38] (Fig. S2). All the prepared bead-type Pd/C catalysts showed the characteristic diffraction peaks of Pd at 2θ values of 40.5°, 46.8°, 68.4° and 82.1°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of the fcc crystal lattice structure. For the AC- and CB-supported Pd catalysts, the broad peaks in the range of 17‒25° suggest an amorphous carbon structure. For the CNT- and CNF-supported Pd catalysts, the broad peak at 17‒25° was observed, along with a sharp peak at 25° The catalysts both displayed a characteristic peak of the C (002) plane, along with a mixture of disordered and ordered carbon with an amorphous structure [39]. FE-TEM was used to study the Pd dispersion and the average particle size of Pd (Fig. 6 ). The average size was determined from 100 Pd nanoparticles. The sizes of the deposited Pd particles in the Pd/AC-AB, Pd/CB-AB, Pd/CNT-AB and Pd/CNF-AB were 14.9, 2.9, 3.4, and 4.9 nm, respectively. Compared to the other catalysts, Pd/AC-AB had the largest average Pd particle size (14.9 nm). The larger Pd particle size observed in Pd/AC-AB can be attributed to two factors: 1) lack of mesopores, and 2) weak interaction between Pd and activated carbon. Mesoporous carbon materials could enhance the drawbacks of microporous structure of AC, such as insufficient anchor sites and the aggregation of metal nanoparticles [40]. Furthermore, the primary factor influencing the Pd particle size on AC is the surface extent within meso- and macropores [41,42]. The weak interaction between Pd and support can arise the mobility of Pd nanoparticles on the carbon surface [43,44]. For Pd/AC-AB embedded in alginate, the decreased mesopore volume of Pd/AC-AB resulted in a comparatively larger Pd particle size. In contrast, in the case of Pd/CB-AB with relatively the highest mesopore volume, the catalyst had the smallest particle size, with a narrow Pd particle size distribution, resulting in strong interactions between the Pd particles and the CB surface [45–47]. Agglomeration of the Pd nanoparticles was observed in Pd/CNF-AB and Pd/CNT-AB. Table 1 presents the Pd dispersion in the bead-type Pd/C catalysts, determined by the pulsed chemisorption of CO. For all of the catalysts, the Pd dispersion ranged from 3.3 % to 23 %, with different carbons significantly influencing the Pd dispersion. Among the bead-type Pd/C catalysts, the Pd/CB-AB catalyst exhibited the highest Pd dispersion (23 %), whereas the lowest dispersion was observed for the Pd/AC-AB (3.3 %) catalyst. We suggest that Pd dispersion is associated with the Pd particle size and Pd size distribution, influenced by the high mesopore volume indicative of small Pd particle sizes in bead-type catalysts. The small and uniformly distributed Pd particles with the highest mesoporous structure in Pd/CB-AB contribute to the formation of highly dispersed catalyst. 3.2 Furfural hydrogenation over bead-type Pd/C catalysts The catalytic performance of the prepared bead-type Pd/C catalysts was evaluated by liquid-phase FF hydrogenation to investigate the effect of the carbon support. The experiments were performed under 20 bar of H2 at 35 ℃ for 4 h; the FF conversion and product selectivity are summarized in Table 3 . FF can be converted into four major products: FAL, THFAL, THFF, and 2-MF. FAL is produced by hydrogenation of the carbonyl group of FF, whereas THF is formed via hydrogenation of the furan ring of FF. THFAL is generated by the over-hydrogenation of FAL, and 2-MF is generated by the hydrogenolysis of FA. The major products of the reaction were FAL and THFAL. It has been reported that the use of an alcohol solvent reduces the C = O group or the furan ring during the hydrogenation of FF [48]. The FF conversion decreased in the following order: Pd/CB-AB (99.8 %) > Pd/CNT-AB (86.0 %) > Pd/CNF-AB (64.0 %) > Pd/AC-AB (44.4 %). The Pd/CB-AB catalyst exhibited the highest FF conversion (99.9 %) and THFAL selectivity (92 %) owing to its large specific surface area and high pore volume. Selective adsorption on fine particles primarily targets the C=C bond, thereby enhancing the selectivity for saturated compounds [49]. Thus, the lack of FF conversion and THFAL selectivity for the Pd/AC-AB catalysts may be due to their larger Pd particle size and lower Pd dispersion compared to those of the other catalysts. The catalytic performance is affected by several factors. The major factor contributing to the high performance of bead-type Pd/C catalysts is the large exposed Pd surface area due to the high dispersion of Pd. Moreover, the large pore volumes of the catalysts facilitated transfer of the FF molecules inside the catalyst pores, which minimized steric hindrance [50,51]. The high mesoporosity of the catalyst structure provided active sites for the Pd nanoparticles, allowing for the Pd to be deposited and stabilized in the mesopores of the catalyst, resulting in high dispersion. The Pd dispersion in the bead-type Pd/C catalysts differed owing to the different structures of the carbon supports. The correlation between the Pd dispersion and FF conversion is shown in Fig. 7 . To investigate the reaction pathway and product selectivity, the effect of the reaction time on FF hydrogenation over the Pd/CB-AB catalyst was evaluated at 35 ℃ under 20 bar of H2 over the course of 15 to 240 min (Fig. 8 ). The FF conversion increased with the reaction time, and reached 100 % after 2 h. A possible reaction pathway for the hydrogenation of FF is shown in Scheme 1 . There are two reaction pathways for the production of FF to THFAL: the ring hydrogenation of the furan ring yielding THFF and the C=O hydrogenation resulting in FAL. The selectivity for THFAL decreased after 1 h and then increased. The selectivity for THFF was lower and remained constant over time, indicating that most of the FF was converted to FAL, and THFAL was formed by the over-hydrogenation of FAL. The Pd/CB-AB catalyst afforded the optimal catalytic activity, with 99.9 % FF conversion and 92 % THFAL selectivity at a reaction time of 4 h. The reusability of Pd/CB-AB was evaluated under 20 bar of H2 at 35 ℃ over the course of 4 h (Fig. 9 ). Excellent catalytic stability is an important factor for industrial applications. After the reaction, the bead-type Pd/C catalyst was easily separated by filtration, followed by washing with distilled water [17]. The freshly washed, bead-type catalysts were dried and reused for three consecutive cycles. A comparative analysis between the used and fresh catalysts was conducted using TGA (Fig. 9(b)) to observe the amount of coke formation. The results revealed an approximately 10 % lower weight loss in the used catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst, which can be indicated of coke formation [52]. The FF conversion obtained with the recycled bead-type Pd/C catalyst decreased minimally after three cycles and the selectivity for THFAL decreased slightly 88.9 % to 81.2 %, whereas those for the other compounds increased. Deactivation of the catalyst is attributed to the formation of the coke on the catalyst. Bead-type Pd/C catalysts showed a decreasing FF conversion and THFAL selectivity compared to powder catalyst (Fig. S3). Shaping of the catalyst resulted in deactivation of catalytic performance due to decreased specific surface area and the addition of a binder [10]. Despite the excellent catalytic performance of the powder catalyst, homogeneous catalysts present challenges in terms of separation from the mixture and possessed the potential for environmental contamination. The reaction mixture of Pd/CB and Pd/CB-AB is shown in Fig. S4. Many studies have focused on alginate as a catalyst support, aiming to develop in eco-friendly method while achieving high catalytic performance. Xia et al. demonstrated that a small amount of Ba2+ ions, used as the alginate crosslinking agent, maintained excellent catalytic activity and reusability of alginate hydrogels, making them suitable as a catalyst support [12]. Wang et al. reported that Pd-loaded cationic nanocellulose alginate hydrogel bead catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction, showing reusability and verifying the concept of green/sustainable polymers, including nanocellulose and alginate [16]. Ma et al. observed that incorporating CNT with alginate showed excellent catalytic activity in cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation, where Ca ions in the alginate bead acted as promoters [23]. Previous investigations have suggested that alginate is a promising material for catalyst supports, and many studies have aimed to incorporate reinforcing agents with alginate to enhance catalytic activity and stability, facilitating easy separation and reusability of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion Bead-type supports were successfully synthesized using alginate by employing various carbon materials during the gelation process, and bead-type Pd/C catalysts were prepared by a chemical reduction method. The carbon structures affected the morphologies of the catalyst surface, and larger carbon particles resulted in a smooth catalyst surface. The physical properties of the carbon, such as the pore volume and specific surface area, significantly influenced the physical properties of the catalysts. Pd/CB-AB, which had the highest specific surface area and pore volume, exhibited the smallest Pd particle size with high dispersion. The morphology is attributed to the anchoring sites for Pd provided by the mesoporous carbon structure. A comparative investigation of the catalytic performance for FF hydrogenation was conducted in the liquid phase. Pd/CB-AB afforded the highest FF conversion of 99 %, with a selectivity of 92 %. The large pore volume and specific surface area of Pd/CB-AB facilitated rapid adsorption/diffusion during Pd-catalyzed FF hydrogenation, and the highly dispersed Pd on the catalyst surface contributed to the increased catalytic efficiency. The macroscale size of the bead-type catalyst facilitates easy handling during both the reaction and recovery processes in liquid-phase reactions. The proper selection of a carbon support composed of CB can facilitate the development of high-performance catalysts with potential practical applications in industry. coredata.dc:description: In green heterogeneous catalytic systems, alginate has emerged as a promising material for transforming powder catalysts into solid forms because of its sustainability and non-toxicity. Herein, the effect of carbon supports, including activated carbon (AC), carbon black (CB), carbon nanotubes (CNT), and carbon nanofibers (CNF), on a bead-type Pd/alginate-carbon catalyst was studied. Bead-type supports were synthesized by alginate gelation, and Pd-supported bead-type catalysts were prepared by a chemical reduction method. The catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of furfural was evaluated. Physical properties such as the specific surface area and pore volume of the carbon support greatly influenced the properties of the bead-type Pd/C catalyst. Pd/CB-alginate bead (AB), which had the highest specific surface area and pore volume, exhibited the smallest Pd particle size and dispersion, resulting in the highest catalytic performance. Additionally, the catalyst exhibited the highest FF conversion of 99 % and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol selectivity of 92 % under 20 bar of H2 at 35 ℃ for 4 h.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of physicochemical properties of carbons on the performance of bead-type Pd/C catalysts for furfural hydrogenation
